COS220/221 Help and Tips

This page is intended as a resource to help you avoid common point deductions as a COS220 or COS221 student.

While I have your attention: pick up your homework! I made this page because every semester many students do not do this, and they miss my notes. Help me help you!

General Assignment Notes

  • All assignments must start with a comment stating your name and the name and purpose of the assignment.

  • Global variables are forbidden unless specifically requested or needed. The only time you'll need to do this is when more than one function needs to reference a variable that you for whatever reason can't pass in as an argument. When in doubt, don't.

  • When you start writing functions, you must include PRE and POST comments on both your function prototypes and definitions. Not doing this at all typically results in a "no credit".

  • You must submit your assignment with screenshots of the console showing what is asked for in the assignment. You will not receive credit if this is not done.

  • If you submit a screenshot of your code instead of printing it out, you will not receive credit. Code files are more or less just .txt files with a different extension, and Visual Studio has a print option. Similarly, please don't paste your code into Word and print it from there; it will mangle your formatting. If you can't print from your IDE, paste the code into Notepad on Windows or TextEdit on OSX and print from there.

  • Excessively messy code will not be accepted. This includes excessive word wrap and improper indentation/bracket placement. See "Pay attention to formatting" below.

Recommended Code Style

It's important to maintain a consistent set of rules for how you name certain types of variables. Establishing and keeping to your own set of rules for this will help you see at a glance what a named token does in your code. See Microsoft's page on casing for definitions of Pascal and Camel Casing.

Rules of thumb:

  • ALL_CAPS for const names (you'll lose points if you don't do this one)

  • PascalCasing for function names

  • camelCasing for variable and parameter names (and everything else)

An example of each:

int someNumber = 0;             //Variable name is camelCased
float someOtherNumber = 5.5;    //Variable name is camelCased
const int SOME_CONSTANT = 5;    //Const name is all caps, with underscores separating words

//Function name is PascalCased, parameter name is camelCased
void SomeFunction(int someParameter){
    //Some code here
}

Now if we encounter someNumber anywhere else in the code, we know that it's a variable without needing to look at its declaration. Similarly, we now know at a glance that SOME_CONSTANT is a constant variable from its casing. Reducing the amount of things you need to mentally juggle is very useful, so take advantage of this!

Give your variables descriptive names

Suppose in the following code we have to choose a name from one of these lines to represent the average weight of a group of packages. Which one would you pick?

float n;
float apw;
float avgPkgWt;
float averagePackageWeight;

We want line 4, or averagePackageWeight as the name. n is a bad name for any variable unless you're doing some mathematical formula or using it as a counting variable (e.g. for(int i=0; i<10; i++){ ... }). apw is getting there, but it's still impossible to tell what it is from the name alone. avgPkgWt is better still, and it would be fine accompanied by a good comment. However, averagePackageWeight is the most desirable because it's self-documenting; that is, you can tell what the variable does without having to look at the comment next to its declaration. When in doubt, go with plain English. If the variable name ends up being very long, it's fine to abbreviate.

Comment your variable declarations

It's boring, but you need to do it to keep yourself organized. The less you have to think while programming, the better; the benefit of commenting your code well is that you don't have to worry about forgetting what certain things do. Comment as you go -- it will help you as you do the work and you won't have to take the time to go back through and do it when you're done.

You must comment all of your variable declarations on homework assignments. See the following:

int mediumPackageCount;       //The total number of medium-sized packages
int largePackageCount;        //The total number of large-sized packages

Note that the comments tell you what the variables are for. For example:

float averagePackageWeight;   //Average                           //Bad comment
float averagePackageWeight;   //Number                            //Really bad comment
float averagePackageWeight;   //Average of all package weights    //Good comment

Pay attention to formatting

Curly brackets should get their own lines, with nothing else on them. Everything between each set of them should be indented. Consider the following, where each level of indentation (tab) is shown with a ⟹:

void SomeFunction(int a, int b)
{
⟹int x = 0;
⟹int y = 0;
⟹
⟹if(a <= b)
⟹{
⟹⟹x = 1;
⟹⟹if(a == b)
⟹⟹{
⟹⟹⟹y = 1;
⟹⟹}
⟹}
⟹else
⟹{
⟹⟹//Some other code here
⟹}
⟹
⟹int w = 3;
}

Line 1 defines the function name and parameters. After the parentheses comes a set of curly brackets (lines 2 and 20), in between which you put the body of the function. Note that here each bracket gets its own line, and everything "inside" of these brackets gets one more level of indentation than the brackets. We can now see visually without having to look at the brackets that lines 3-19 compose the body of the function.

You may also write your opening brackets on the same line as the parentheses:

if(x == 0){
    //Some code here
}

Personally I prefer this, but there are arguments for both ways of doing it and I'm not going to deduct points for your choice. The important thing is to be consistent. Choose a rule and follow it every time. As an aside, the IDE you're using will probably try to enforce some type of formatting whenever you make a new line or perform an autocomplete, which is great! Let it do its thing.

Function definitions go after the main() function

We want the main() function to appear in a code file before any other functions. However, the compiler has to "see" these functions before main() is evaluated in order to build the program correctly. To give it a hint, so to speak, we use function prototypes. These tell the compiler that the function does indeed exist, but that its behavior will be defined elsewhere. Put simply, you declare your prototypes before the main function, and then define them after the main function. An example:

#include <string>

int someFunction(const int x, int y); //Prototype declaration

int main() {
    int result = someFunction(2, 3);
    return 0;
}

int someFunction(const int x, int y){ //Prototype definition
    return x + y;
}

Without the prototype, this program will not build. The compiler will tell you that the function does not exist when it tries to read line 6 -- this is why we must declare the prototype in advance. The prototype is used so that you can use your function anywhere in your code, regardless of where it is defined.

The reason for all this is that eventually you will be working with header files. Line 1 is an example of an imported header. When you write your own header, you can declare your prototypes there and import them with one line at the beginning of the file, just like in line 1. This is an important detail and will become necessary as you start working with classes and object-oriented programming.

Tips

  • When using a function that asks for a path string, the path you give is (usually) relative to your executable. So if you're in the debug configuration and your path is "someFile.txt", it's going to look for a file with that name in the debug directory (depending on your IDE).

  • Don't be afraid to Google functions if you don't know what they do. Coding languages as a whole are very, very well documented online.

  • Read the assignment carefully. If you're asked to implement functions given on the page or described in class and you don't do it, it typically results in you needing to resubmit with changes to get credit for that portion of the assignment.

  • Comment your code as you go. If you write some code and think "that was complicated", that's a good indicator that you should leave a comment for your future self.
